caption_original:
On Tuesday August 29 the Canadian Coast Guard successfully located four hikers who had lost their way along the Lighthouse Trail at Killarney. The Ontario Provincial Police requested assistance via the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre in Trenton Ontario.

The Coast Guard's inshore rescue boat crew stationed at Britt was tasked to search for 3 females, one male and their dog. 

The Coast Guard brought the group aboard their fast rescue craft and transported them back to Killarney. All were in good condition.

Photo caption: From left to right Stephen Pitman, Mollie King, and Keith Pettinger of the Canadian Coast Guard Inshore Rescue Boat station at Britt. The crew assisted four hikers and their dog at Tar Vat Bay Tuesday August 29 2017
caption_cleaned: On Tuesday August the Canadian Coast Guard successfully located four hikers who had lost their way along the Lighthouse Trail at Killarney. The Ontario Provincial Police requested assistance via the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre in Trenton Ontario. The Coast Guard's inshore rescue boat crew stationed at Britt was tasked to search for females, one male and their dog. The Coast Guard brought the group aboard their fast rescue craft and transported them back to Killarney. All were in good condition. Photo caption: From left to right Stephen Pitman, Mollie King, and Keith Pettinger of the Canadian Coast Guard Inshore Rescue Boat station at Britt. The crew assisted four hikers and their dog at Tar Vat Bay Tuesday August

caption_original: The CCGS Henry Larsen welcomed 241 guests onboard during a five hour visit in Clyde River, Nunavut last month. Guests received a tour of the vessel and insight into what we do in the North. We even celebrated the visit with ice cream and freshly baked cookies!

caption_original: A/Assistant Commissioner Coast Guard Atlantic Region, Don Llewellyn, and Captain Wayne Duffett met with Captain Patrick Armstrong and his senior crew aboard the USCG Maple during a recent port call in St. John’s as part of ongoing collaboration between the Canadian and American Coast Guard. Coincidentally, Captain Marc Rothwell who retired from the Canadian Coast Guard in January 2016 as Commanding Officer of the CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent, was working aboard the Maple as Ice Navigator when she visited St. John’s and enjoyed reconnecting with former colleagues.

Coincidentally, Captain Marc Rothwell who retired from the Canadian Coast Guard in January as Commanding Officer of the CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent, was working aboard the Maple as Ice Navigator when she visited St. John’s and enjoyed reconnecting with former colleagues.

caption_original: The CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier departed July 3rd for the Arctic. Aboard the ship were Canadian Hydrographic Services vessels True North and Whiskey Jack, heading North to begin their work. A stop was made in Dutch Harbour, Alaska to pick up American scientists joining the team.

caption_original:
Our crew aboard CCGS Constable Carrière, one of our mid-shore patrol vessels that provides maritime security on the Great Lakes, is honoured to attend the Grand Haven Coast Guard Festival in western Michigan. Each year, this festival in Grand Haven, which is known as Coast Guard City USA, attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors, and honours those who have sacrificed their lives in the service of their country. The two Coast Guards deliver a multitude of maritime services including Search and Rescue, Environmental Response, Icebreaking, Marine Communications and Traffic Services, Aids to Navigation, Maritime Security and Waterways Management.
Photos: Petty Officer 2nd Class Lauren Steenson, U.S. Coast Guard
caption_cleaned: Our crew aboard CCGS Constable Carrière, one of our mid-shore patrol vessels that provides maritime security on the Great Lakes, is honoured to attend the Grand Haven Coast Guard Festival in western Michigan. Each year, this festival in Grand Haven, which is known as Coast Guard City USA, attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors, and honours those who have sacrificed their lives in the service of their country. The two Coast Guards deliver a multitude of maritime services including Search and Rescue, Environmental Response, Icebreaking, Marine Communications and Traffic Services, Aids to Navigation, Maritime Security and Waterways Management. Photos: Petty Officer nd Class Lauren Steenson, U.S. Coast Guard

caption_original: Every summer, the Canadian Coast Guard transports members of Environment and Climate Change Canada’s Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS) to Country Island (NS) to study the seabird population. We recently had special guests Dr. Roberta Bondar and Professor Bonnie Patterson, Chair of the Roberta Bondar Foundation, aboard the CCGS Bickerton, to learn more about the work of the CWS and to take pictures for the Foundation’s work connecting people with nature through art. Thank you to Commanding Officer Mundle and the crew for the smooth voyage!
caption_cleaned: Every summer, the Canadian Coast Guard transports members of Environment and Climate Change Canada’s Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS) to Country Island (NS) to study the seabird population. We recently had special guests Dr. Roberta Bondar and Professor Bonnie Patterson, Chair of the Roberta Bondar Foundation, aboard the CCGS Bickerton, to learn more about the work of the CWS and to take pictures for the Foundation’s work connecting people with nature through art. Thank you to Commanding Officer Mundle and the crew for the smooth voyage!

caption_original: The Commissioner of the Canadian Coast Guard Jeffery Hutchinson met with employees in Sarnia Ontario Tuesday August 1. Canadian Coast Guard Marine Communications and Vessel Traffic Services officer Julie MacRae showed Commissioner Hutchinson the latest technology used keep ships moving safely and efficiently on the Great Lakes. MCTS employees have a vital role in the maritime search and rescue system as well as vessel traffic management. The Communications centre is located in the federal building in downtown Sarnia. For more information about Commissioner Hutchinson: http://www.ccg-gcc.gc.ca/eng/CCG/Commissioner

caption_original: Our new Canadian Coast Guard Atlantic Coast Guard HQ in St. Johns will include an improved small vessel repair and a rigger/carpentry shop. Here we will fix small rescue boats like fast rescue crafts and inshore rescue boats, and build what we need to support navigational aids and structures.

caption_original:
On July 31, Adam Erland, Regional Supervisor Maritime Search and Rescue for Joint Rescue Coordination Centre Halifax, joined other VIPs for a tour of the United States Coast Guard Cutter EAGLE while it was in port for the annual Tall Ships Festival in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The delegation included USCGC EAGLE Captain Matthew T. Meilstrup and his Executive Officer, the U.S. Consulate General for Atlantic Canada Steven S. Giegerich, President and CEO of the Halifax Port Authority Karen Oldfield, City of Halifax Mayor Mike Savage, and representatives from the Halifax Airport Commission and the Halifax Chamber of Commerce.   

The Canadian Coast Guard regularly works with its American counterparts on exercises and training opportunities in support of safety of mariners and the marine environment.
caption_cleaned: On July , Adam Erland, Regional Supervisor Maritime Search and Rescue for Joint Rescue Coordination Centre Halifax, joined other VIPs for a tour of the United States Coast Guard Cutter EAGLE while it was in port for the annual Tall Ships Festival in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The delegation included USCGC EAGLE Captain Matthew T. Meilstrup and his Executive Officer, the U.S. Consulate General for Atlantic Canada Steven S. Giegerich, President and CEO of the Halifax Port Authority Karen Oldfield, City of Halifax Mayor Mike Savage, and representatives from the Halifax Airport Commission and the Halifax Chamber of Commerce. The Canadian Coast Guard regularly works with its American counterparts on exercises and training opportunities in support of safety of mariners and the marine environment.

caption_original:
On August 15th the crew members from fishing vessel (FV) Abigail Grace were evacuated onto the CCGS Leonard J Cowley, in coordination with partners.The FV, which was disabled NE of Resolution Island, Nunavut, was then towed. The tow was safely completed yesterday, passing the FV Abagail Grace safely to a third party who will tow them into St Anthony, NL. Bravo Zulu to the crew and all partners for a successful rescue! Royal Canadian Air Force 

http://ow.ly/D9ka30evEht

The tow was safely completed yesterday, passing the FV Abagail Grace safely to a third party who will tow them into St Anthony, NL. Bravo Zulu to the crew and all partners for a successful rescue! Royal Canadian Air Force

caption_original:
Did you know that the we provide icebreaking services for commercial ships, ferries and fishing vessels in ice-covered Canadian waters, including vessel escorts, harbour breakouts, maintaining shipping routes and providing ice information services. These services:

• ensure safe navigation,
• prevent the formation of ice jams and flooding, and
• maintain shipping routes for maritime commerce.

Learn more at http://www.ccg-gcc.gc.ca/Icebreaking/home

caption_original: Crews from the USCGC Sherman and the CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier recently met on the waters of the Chukchi Sea in the Arctic in July. This professional exchange and social visit at sea involved tours of each other’s ships to understand our different capabilities, discuss interoperability and shared maritime priorities.
